contents.title: Exploring the Digital Ocean `doctl` Utility
contents.description:
I recently had the need to spool up a small ephemeral Linux instance, and wanted to try something new by exploring the Digital Ocean doctl command line utility.
This proved to be an extremely easy way to configure, create, connect, and destroy a Linux box, and I foresee myself using this service even more in the future.

children.value: I recently had the need to spool up a small ephemeral Linux instance, and wanted to try something new by exploring the Digital Ocean

command line utility.
This proved to be an
easy way to configure, create, connect, and destroy a Linux box, and I foresee myself using this service even more in the future.
I recently had the need to spool up a small ephemeral Linux instance, and wanted to try something new by exploring the Digital Ocean

command line utility.
This proved to be an
easy way to configure, create, connect, and destroy a Linux box, and I foresee myself using this service even more in the future.

To start things off, I had to install and setup authentication to Digital Ocean. Doing
this on my Mac machine, I opted to use

props.code:
# install `doctl`
brew install doctl

# setup authentication
doctl auth init

children.value: is fantastic, I instead found myself mostly referencing the outputs of

props.code: doctl compute droplet create --help

children.value: I had to find the image name of the version of Ubuntu I wanted to install:

props.code:
doctl compute image list --public | grep ubuntu-22

# 118857366    22.04 (LTS) x64    snapshot    Ubuntu    ubuntu-22-04-x64    true    7
# 119383150    22.10 x64          snapshot    Ubuntu    ubuntu-22-10-x64    true    7

children.value: And also the slug of the compute size:

props.code:
doctl compute size list

# Slug                  Description    Memory    VCPUs    Disk    Price Monthly    Price Hourly
# s-1vcpu-512mb-10gb    Basic          512       1        10      4.00             0.005950
# s-1vcpu-1gb           Basic          1024      1        25      6.00             0.008930
# s-1vcpu-1gb-amd       Basic AMD      1024      1        25      7.00             0.010420
# s-1vcpu-1gb-intel     Basic Intel    1024      1        25      7.00             0.010420
# s-1vcpu-2gb           Basic          2048      1        50      12.00            0.017860
# s-1vcpu-2gb-amd       Basic AMD      2048      1        50      14.00            0.020830

children.value: # Slug                  Description    Memory    VCPUs    Disk    Price Monthly    Price Hourly
I've also configured a few SSH keys with Digital Ocean, and I can have the key (specified by ID) provisioned to the machine using the

props.code:
doctl compute ssh-key list

# ID      Name    FingerPrint
# 1234    mini    <redacted>

children.value: Also, I wanted to install a few packages to the box upon creation, this can be done easily with the
flag to run an initialization script.

props.code: echo 'apt install -y imagemagick zip' > bootstrap.sh

children.value: Putting it all together, here is the simple command for creating a small compute instance!

props.code:
doctl compute droplet create \
    --image ubuntu-22-10-x64 \
    --size s-1vcpu-512mb-10gb \
    --region nyc1 \
    --ssh-keys 1234 \
    --user-data-file boostrap.sh \
    ephemeral

children.value: Finally, I can connect, do my thing, and destroy the instance.

props.code: doctl compute ssh ephemeral
doctl compute droplet delete --force ephemeral

children.value: All-in-all, I was up and running in about 20 minutes. What a handy utility!

Get the latest Arch Linux image

Vagrant

command under-the-hood, allowing one to enable the guest machine

props.code:
# -*- mode: ruby -*-
# vi: set ft=ruby :

Vagrant.configure("2") do |config|
  config.vm.box = "archlinux/archlinux"
  config.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |vb|
    vb.name = "archlinux"
    vb.customize ['modifyvm', :id, '--usb', 'on']
    vb.customize ['usbfilter', 'add', '1', '--target', :id, '--name', 'SanDisk Ultra Fit', '--vendorid', '0x0781', '--productid', '0x5583']
  end
end

contents.title: Unit Testing in MicroPython with Mocks
contents.description:
Unit testing code for embedded systems can be challenging. While it's possible
to leverage emulators, write side-effect free code, or run tests on the
hardware itself, it's often easiest to unit test the code on your personal
computer with mocked hardware functionality.

children.value:
Unit testing code for embedded systems can be challenging. While it's possible
to leverage emulators, write side-effect free code, or run tests on the
hardware itself, it's often easiest to unit test the code on your personal
computer with mocked hardware functionality.

Unit testing code for embedded systems can be challenging. While it's possible
to leverage emulators, write side-effect free code, or run tests on the
hardware itself, it's often easiest to unit test the code on your personal
computer with mocked hardware functionality.

Mocks allow us to replace the hardware interfacing functionality under-the-hood
with predefined results and side-effects. For example, if there is a piece of
logic that retrieves values from an accelerometer to get a device's
orientation, it would be possible to mock the returned values of the
accelerometer -- allowing us to run the unit tests on a device that does not
have an accelerometer sensor installed.
In this example, we will be unit testing a module named

, that
depends on the MicroPython library

to log the most recent Epoch time to
a file.

props.code:
# time_logger.py

class TimeLogger(object):

    def save_time(self):
        """ Overwrite a file with the most recent Epoch timestamp from `utime`
        """
        with open("LAST_KNOWN_TIME", "w+") as f:
            f.write(str(utime.time()))

children.value: """ Overwrite a file with the most recent Epoch timestamp from `utime`

module is not installed on the machine that the unit
tests on, we must mock

props.code:
# test_time_logger.py

import unittest

from unittest.mock import MagicMock

sys.modules['utime'] = MagicMock()
from time_logger import TimeLogger

children.value: Then, we can write a test that patches the

functionality so that
it returns a value of our choosing -- in this case,

props.code:
class TestTimeLogger(unittest.TestCase):

    def test_save_time(self):
        """ Verify that the Epoch time is written to file
        """
        with unittest.mock.patch("utime.time", return_value=1234):
            t = TimeLogger()
            t.save_time()
            with open("LAST_KNOWN_TIME") as f:
                self.assertEqual("1234", f.read())
